content.text: Recent development efforts focused on improving package functionality and testing. Notable updates include adding basic tests for the OpenAI plugin and enhancing tests for Anthropic, ensuring better reliability and performance.
A major development merge was made to the main branch, consolidating various improvements and updates. This merge ensures that recent changes are integrated into the primary codebase.
A previous merge from the development branch to the main branch was reverted, undoing changes from an earlier update.
A new feature was introduced for Discord testing, expanding the project's capabilities and integration with the platform.
Overall, development efforts included package improvements, new features, and testing enhancements, with contributions from 15 developers and the merging of three pull requests.
A roundup post is being compiled summarizing 12 weeks of 'What Did You Get Done This Week?' spaces, where contributors shared updates on open-source AI and social agents.
The winners of the Sui AI Agent Hackathon have been announced. Check out the full list of winners.
A user shares their journey of engaging with DAOs and AI trading, starting with memecoins and now working on AI traders.
A new UX challenge has emerged: the need for an AI COO to help onboard AI freelancers.

A new plugin for Messari Copilot has been proposed, integrating Messari's AI Toolkit with an Eliza agent to provide crypto market research capabilities. The plugin detects and processes research questions from conversations and queries Messari for insights.

categories.title: ElizaOS Updates: Hackathon Winners, Feature Requests, and Deployment Issues

content.text: elizaOS celebrated the winners of the Sui Agent Typhoon Hackathon, highlighting standout projects powered by Eliza technology, including Build-A-Bot, Mitsui Protocol, and Alberta.
A feature request was made to add support for exSAT blockchain as a plugin in Eliza. The requester expressed willingness to contribute to the development of this feature.

A user reported a port scanning error when deploying a Twitter Eliza agent on Render. Despite multiple attempts to modify environment variables, the issue persisted, and they sought alternative deployment solutions.
A pull request was submitted to sync the main Eliza repository with Jobsy.

ElizaOS currently lacks comprehensive DeFi token analysis capabilities. Users need a way to analyze token contracts for potential risks, get real-time market data, assess social sentiment, and receive automated risk scoring.

The proposed solution is to implement `plugin-expuzi`, which will provide DeFi token analysis through contract analysis via Sui Network integration, market data fetching through CoinGecko, a risk scoring system (0-100), warning detection for suspicious patterns, and social sentiment tracking.

The technical implementation includes core components such as the TokenAuditor class, a risk calculation engine, a contract data fetcher, market data integration, and a social sentiment analyzer. The solution requires Sui Network access, CoinGecko API integration, support for multiple token standards, and comprehensive test coverage.

The pull request for this feature includes the implementation of the new plugin for DeFi token analysis, a comprehensive risk scoring system, integration with CoinGecko for market data, and a Sui network connection for contract analysis. It also introduces a testing framework with MockRuntime.

The changes require updates to the project documentation, including a new README.md in the plugin directory, updates to the main documentation with new plugin capabilities, and added API documentation for the risk scoring system.

Testing instructions include installing dependencies, running plugin tests, and verifying expected results such as passing tests, risk scoring between 0-100, successful market data fetching, and error-free contract analysis.

categories.title: Onchain Communication and Security Against Scams

content.text: With the rise of fake gold and government checkmark accounts, onchain communication could be a more secure alternative. Proper OPSEC makes it harder to hijack private keys compared to social platforms like X or Discord. A potential approach is to train users to verify messages onchain first before relaying them to X, though character limits could be a challenge.

Signing a malicious signature can lead to irreversible consequences. Unlike traditional accounts, there is no way to revoke or recover funds—users must abandon the compromised wallet and start fresh with a new seed phrase.

Scammers are evolving their tactics. In December, they were using gold verification badges, but now they are exploiting grey government badges to appear legitimate. Users should verify accounts carefully to avoid falling for these scams.
High performers in communities often disengage when those who contribute the least complain the most. This pattern is common in volunteer-driven and open-source settings.

One way to support high performers and create a more balanced community is through contribution-based reputation systems. These systems can track on-chain contributions, such as GitHub commits, forum posts, votes, and governance proposals, to measure actual work.
A user expressed interest in trying out the proposed approach for supporting high performers.

categories.title: Fixing Incorrect Image Paths in Korean Documentation

content.text: A bug was identified in the Korean documentation where images were not displaying correctly due to incorrect file paths. The issue was reported in the project repository, highlighting that the Eliza diagram images in the '구조' section were not loading as expected.

A pull request was submitted to fix the incorrect image paths in the Korean documentation. The update ensures that images are properly displayed by correcting the file paths. The change is classified as a low-risk documentation fix and does not affect any functionality or code execution.

categories.title: VRM Optimization and LoRA Training Pipeline

content.text: A GUI-based VRM optimizer allows users to drag and drop multiple VRM files at once, then download all optimized files as a zip. Additionally, the CharacterStudio SDK provides a way to import a library and call functions from the CharacterManager class, though documentation is not yet available.
An open-source VRM-to-LoRA training pipeline is available for users with access to VRM files. The code for this pipeline is accessible online.

categories.title: Wallet Support for Memos in Transactions

content.text: Some wallets support adding memos to transactions, while others do not. Wallets like Rabby, Leap (for certain chains), Phantom (for token2022 standard), and Zcash (with encrypted memos) allow memos. However, Magic Eden and MetaMask do not support memos.

Tokens using the token2022 standard, such as those from @daosdotfun, allow memos in transactions when using compatible wallets like Phantom. In contrast, Pumpfun tokens do not support memos. DAOs can leverage this feature to share wallets in advance and use on-chain messages for backup communication.

categories.title: Advancements in AI Agent Integration and Onboarding

content.text: The concept of horizontally integrated agents is gaining traction, with the potential for open-source GitHub templates to create entire teams of AI agents for project management. With the upcoming release of elizaOS v2, it may become even easier to generate predefined roles for these agents.

A new onboarding system for AI agents has been refined, allowing them to onboard in their own voice and acquire necessary information. Additional tasks have been implemented to handle follow-ups, indicating promising progress in agent automation.
